questions.question: According to Grisez, marriage's ordination to procreation sets its essential requirements in the sense that:

choices.A: Polygamy may be tolerated because the duty to procreate takes precedence over marital fidelity.
choices.B: The long, involved process of raising children to maturity requires a stable, loving environment.
choices.C: The fact that the sterile cannot fulfill marriage's primary purpose means they cannot truly marry.

questions.question: According to Grisez, the practice of arranged marriage can prevent the formation of valid marital bonds, such as when:

choices.A: The parties are mistaken about the indissolubility of marriage, but do not exclude it by a positive act.
choices.B: The spouses themselves consent to the arrangements made on their behalf and cooperate in them.
choices.C: Marriage customs give no importance to the woman's consent, making marriage a mere transaction.

questions.question: According to St. Augustine, marriage is good:

choices.A: Finally, in as much as marriage is an end to which other human activity is directed, and is thus a principle for human action.
choices.B: Intrinsically, insofar as people judge marriage to be personally fulfilling and so choose marriage for its own sake.
choices.C: All of the above.
choices.D: Instrumentally, insofar as it helps realize other goods such as the procreation of offspring and avoids evils such as sexual sin.

questions.question: Especially since the Second Vatican Council, the Catholic theological tradition has understood marriage to be:

choices.A: An instrumental good, inferior to virginity but nevertheless praiseworthy as a means of begetting offspring and avoiding sexual sin.
choices.B: An intrinsic evil, since it resulted in procreation and thereby perpetuated the cycle of reincarnation by preventing the ascent of souls.
choices.C: An intrinsic good, founded upon spousal love and for this reason characterized by fidelity, permanence, and an openness to children.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, heterosexual unions of the sterile are:

choices.A: True marriages, since the expression of conjugal love through sexual cooperation is an intrinsic good.
choices.B: True marriages, since coitus unites spouses bodily and organically, whether or not conception results.
choices.C: Not true marriages, since their intercourse is non-generative and for this reason merely masturbatory.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, homosexual unions are not as comprehensive as marriages are, since:

choices.A: Homosexuals are incapable of accepting children as gifts of God and instead treat them as entitlements.
choices.B: Heterosexual couples experience sexual pleasure as a single entity, in virtue of their organic bodily union.
choices.C: Homosexual intercourse does not unite the parties organically in the pursuit of bodily goods in common.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, procreation perfects marriage in the sense that:

choices.A: Couples remain only putatively married until they have conceived a child together.
choices.B: Having children gives men a reason to stay committed to women they do not love.
choices.C: Procreation unfolds marital love, giving it new avenues for expression and growth.

questions.question: The fact that marriage is a commitment to the good of one's spouse means it is a _______ good, while the fact that it involves cooperation toward the realization of bodily goods means it is a _______ good.

choices.A: Substantive / Intelligible
choices.B: Existential / Substantive
choices.C: Substantive / Existential

questions.question: The Second Vatican Council did not repeat the classical distinction between primary and secondary ends of marriage because:

choices.A: Identifying and ranking ends (or purposes) of marriage would have suggested marriage was merely a means, not an end in itself.
choices.B: It was not necessary to emphasize the secondary importance of love, since few people saw this as an important feature of marriage.
choices.C: Affirming marriage's orientation to procreation would have complicated the Council's plans to authorize the use of contraceptives.

questions.question: To speak of marriage as an open-ended community, as Grisez does, means that:

choices.A: Marriage is not intrinsically monogamous, given the sociological fact of polygamy.
choices.B: It is impossible to bind oneself to another irrevocably, since the future is uncertain.
choices.C: Marriage is an unreserved commitment to the good of one's spouse, come what may.

questions.question: When Grisez says that couples cannot make their marital union exclusive and permanent, he means that:

choices.A: It is bad if spouses are unfaithful or divorce, but their situation can be approved if they repent for a time.
choices.B: Marriage must be subjected to intense social pressures in order to elicit good behavior and curb infidelity.
choices.C: These qualities are not subject matter for negotiation, but derive from the very nature of marriage itself.

questions.question: A spouse would violate MR7 ("Forbearance") by:

choices.A: Having an affair with his or her spouse's friend or sibling after learning that spouse had been unfaithful.
choices.B: Taking up cigar smoking, indoors, specifically to signal his or her dislike of the other spouse's smoking.
choices.C: Threatening to divorce and take the children unless the other spouse seeks treatment for alcoholism.

questions.question: According to Grisez, overly sharp gender role divisions in married and family life are undesirable, since:

choices.A: The dignity of women depends upon their functional equality with men in all areas of human activity.
choices.B: Men who cannot cook, clean, or otherwise keep house are more easily manipulated by their wives.
choices.C: Excessive specialization endangers the good of the family, in case one spouse is ill, injured, or dies.

questions.question: Christian spouses suffering from infertility model MCR1 ("Humility") when they:

choices.A: Continue cultivating the qualities of good parents, as by supporting friends or relatives who are parents.
choices.B: Approach friends or relatives to see if any would be willing to carry the couple's embryo as a surrogate.
choices.C: Recognize their condition as God's way of calling them to conceive through in vitro fertilization instead.

questions.question: Grisez suggests that couples should be cautious in following advice and guidance regarding marriage, since:

choices.A: Each marriage is unique, and no one else can discern for spouses what is God's will for their marriage.
choices.B: Many counselors operate on assumptions and offer advice inconsistent with Christian moral norms.
choices.C: Christian faith requires that all confidence be placed in divine providence, not in vain human learning.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, it would be appropriate for a Catholic married to someone of a different faith to:

choices.A: Reflect every day on the happy marriage they could have had, if only they had married another Catholic.
choices.B: Prioritize the peace of the family by converting or letting their children be brought up as non-Catholics.
choices.C: Separate, since their religious differences have already rendered the marital common good unattainable.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, legitimate limitations of marital cooperation might include:

choices.A: Deferring childbearing because of one spouse's prior responsibility to care for an elderly dependent parent.
choices.B: Letting a Protestant spouse attend Bible study at his or her own church, rather than going to Catholic Mass.
choices.C: Procuring a vasectomy or a tubal ligation once the spouses have borne their preferred number of children.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, voluntarily entertaining thoughts of not being married to one's spouse is gravely wrong, since:

choices.A: The law of attraction dictates that whatever a person focuses his energy on comes to him.
choices.B: The marital bond depends upon the continuing consent of both spouses for its existence.
choices.C: Such thoughts are already contrary to marital love and often the first step toward adultery.

questions.question: In cases of marital conflict, an application of MR6 ("Honesty") or MCR6 ("Purity of Heart") could be:

choices.A: To reflect on how one may have contributed to the conflict and to be ready to ask for and offer pardon.
choices.B: To prompt the offending party to apologize by engaging in passive aggression and withholding affection.
choices.C: To preserve the peace of the family by concealing one's feelings, such as by denying one's anger or pain.

questions.question: The norm that spouses should maintain a common domestic life and be present to one another more or less continuously admits of exceptions, such as when one of them:

choices.A: Takes a job requiring lengthy travel abroad, even against the other spouse's wishes.
choices.B: Has social commitments which consume a large amount of his or her leisure time.
choices.C: Has gravely harmed the other or marital communion through violence or adultery.

questions.question: To say, as the Catholic tradition does, that spouses share in a partnership of the whole of life means that spouses:

choices.A: Must define themselves in terms of their marriage, renouncing their sense of individuality for its sake.
choices.B: Commit themselves to advancing the holistic good of one another for as long as they both shall live.
choices.C: Remain bound to one another for as long as they derive emotional satisfaction from their marriages.

questions.question: Catholic parents should help their children prepare for the sacrament of confirmation by:

choices.A: Not insisting that the children attend Mass on Sundays, so that their decision to attend will be genuinely free.
choices.B: Teaching them new languages in anticipation of their receiving charismatic gifts, especially speaking in tongues.
choices.C: Helping children understand their gifts and limitations, and how these can be used in the service of the gospel.

questions.question: Divorced or separated parents should cooperate in their children's personal formation by:

choices.A: Preferring a full custody arrangement to shared custody, to relieve one of the parents of the burdens of child care.
choices.B: Teaching children what a good spouse should be like by explaining how the other parent caused the marriage to fail.
choices.C: Discuss the children's behavioral problems with one another and enforce similar discipline in their respective homes.

questions.question: Illegitimate uses of parental authority in respect of children's vocational discernment could include:

choices.A: Sending a child proficient in chemistry to a science high school rather than one specializing in the arts.
choices.B: Conditioning financial support for the child's college education on his or her pursuing a certain major.
choices.C: Forbidding a child from entering consecrated life, so that he or she might take over the family business.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, a child whose parents order him or her to lie in order to help the parents evade the consequences of wrongdoing appropriately honors them (Ex. 20:12) by:

choices.A: Lying, since children are subject to their parents' authority and thus ought to obey them in all things
choices.B: Lying, but in a way which exaggerates the parents' guilt, as retribution for pressuring the child to lie.
choices.C: Refusing to lie, since parental authority lacks all force insofar as it is invoked as an incitement to sin.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, parents' responsibility for educating their children is best described as:

choices.A: Secondary, since children's wellbeing implicates the common good, the responsibility for which vests chiefly in the state.
choices.B: Primary, since they brought their children into the world, but cannot do everything necessary to raise them themselves.
choices.C: Exclusive, since parents are accountable to Go alone and no authority outside the family is competent to judge them.

questions.question: In a Catholic perspective, the right of children to an adequate moral formation obliges parents to:

choices.A: Give their children anything they ask for, since this will help children learn by making their own mistakes.
choices.B: Appeal to rational motives for choosing what is good while avoiding invocations of authority, if possible.
choices.C: Control their children's environment to some extent, as by removing potential bad influences upon them.

questions.question: Parents can help children develop their ability to reason and make responsible choices by:

choices.A: Involving children in the planning of meals and in purchasing and preparing ingredients.
choices.B: Working long hours or leaving off certain household chores, to teach them resilience.
choices.C: Refusing even children's reasonable requests without explanation, to teach them docility.

questions.question: Parents would violate MR2 ("Do not act individualistically for the sake of intelligible goods") by:

choices.A: Improving their children's chances of getting into a good university by doing their homework for them.
choices.B: Refusing a child's offer to help with chores because his or her involvement would slow down the work
choices.C: Reserving most of their paychecks for family expenses and giving their children only a small allowance.

questions.question: Parents would violate MR5 ("Do not show partiality unless such is required by intelligible goods themselves") by:

choices.A: Spending surplus money on dental work for themselves, rather than buying their child a new video game console.
choices.B: Excluding a gay or lesbian child from family events to which his or her heterosexual siblings are invited.
choices.C: Not attending one child's college graduation because of a medical emergency involving his or her sibling.

questions.question: Parents' responsibility for their children's religious formation obliges them to:

choices.A: Select a good godparent, prioritizing candidates who can improve the family's finances or prestige.
choices.B: Defer baptism and religious instruction until they are old enough to decide about these matters themselves.
choices.C: Send their children to a Catholic school, even if its curriculum and policies openly contradict the Catholic faith.

questions.question: A Catholic whose parents request that their ashes be scattered rather than interred or inurned appropriately honors father and mother (Ex 20:12) by:

choices.A: Carrying out the request, since the duty of filial obedience is more fundamental than Catholic canon law.
choices.B: Interring or inurning an aliquot of the ashes, then scattering the remainder in obedience to one's parents.
choices.C: Interring or inurning all of the ashes, since scattering them would be an act of desecration, not of honor.

questions.question: A minor who discovers herself to be pregnant out of wedlock would model MR8 ("benevolence") by:

choices.A: Placing the child for adoption, if she is not able to marry the father and cannot care for the child herself.
choices.B: Procuring an abortion, to spare herself from the complications and difficulties motherhood would entail.
choices.C: Using any means necessary, including blackmail, to compel the father to fulfill his responsibilities to her.

questions.question: All else being equal, the Catholic tradition regards a sin (e.g., physical violence, cursing) committed against one's parents as _______ serious than/as one committed against a stranger, since _______.

choices.A: Equally/All the baptized are children of God and share equally in his grace (Gal. 3:28).
choices.B: More / Children owe parents a special gratitude for having given them life (Sir. 3:1-11).
choices.C: Less / Familial bonds are bonds of love, which "remembers not wrongs" (I Cor. 13:5).

questions.question: Among other reasons, the Catholic Church prohibits eulogies at funeral liturgies because:

choices.A: The effects of God's grace in a believer's life cannot be numbered; thus, such an attempt is blasphemous.
choices.B: Reflecting on the good qualities of the deceased would deny catharsis to their aggrieved family members.
choices.C: Glorifying the deceased in this way obscures the importance of praying that God will be merciful to them.

questions.question: An adult child would model MCR7 ("peacemaking") by:

choices.A: Severing ties with an abusive parent and concentrating fully on raising her own family.
choices.B: Respecting a parent's autonomy by letting him drive, even though he is legally blind.
choices.C: Praying for a neglectful parent and providing for his or her decent support in old age.

questions.question: An adult child would violate the responsibility to care for his or her elderly parents by:

choices.A: Refusing to buy cigarettes for an elderly parent suffering from emphysema and chronic bronchitis.
choices.B: Terminating all financial support for a dependent parent, to provide for his own child's education.
choices.C: Asking an able-bodied parent who lives with her to help with light household chores or childcare.

questions.question: Catholic families should relate to obstinately sinful or fallen-away members by:

choices.A: Never bringing up the situation or discussing it with them, to preserve the peace of the family.
choices.B: Severing all ties to induce their repentance and to protect the family from their sinful influence.
choices.C: Praying for them and remaining present in their lives, taking care to avoid condoning their sins.

questions.question: Grisez advises women who find themselves pregnant out of wedlock to marry:

choices.A: Immediately, so that their families will be spared embarrassment and their child will have a secure future.
choices.B: After the birth of the child, if ever, so as to avoid making an important vocational choice under pressure.
choices.C: Never, since they have defiled themselves by fornicating and so are forever unmarriageable in righteousness.

questions.question: The Catholic tradition understands the primary and specific contribution of the family to society to be:

choices.A: Preparing family members to enter and sustain loving interpersonal relationships.
choices.B: Providing for the common good through the exercise of political authority.
choices.C: Developing the earth and its resources, turning them to the service of humanity.

questions.question: An adult child who disagrees with his own parents about parenting styles would respond appropriately by:

choices.A: Deferring to the parent's advice completely, since children remain subject to their parents in adulthood.
choices.B: Considering the merits of the parent's advice and calmly expressing what may be unreasonable about it.
choices.C: Refusing to listen to the parent's advice, since the adult child alone knows what is best for his children.
